Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Laser Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy System for Alvin
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past two decades, a new spectroscopic technique called laser induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) has been developed and has gained favor for in situ field measurements in hostile environments. The goal of this proposal is to build a LIBS system suitable for deployment on Alvin with pressure cases and interfaces that are Alvin compatible. Once constructed, the PIs will re-validate the laboratory measurements in a test tank. At the end of this phase, they should have a working LIBS system that is compatible with Alvin, and that has been validated in a real water environment.

Broader Impacts:

The work itself addressing the advancement of the technology and the measurement environment are state-of-the-art research and development. The system configuration and results in this harsh environment will benefit other applications for real-time monitoring, including industrial processes and space exploration. Additionally, the research will lead to several student PhD dissertations, and collaborations among international research teams.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded the design, construction and laboratory validation of a laser induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) spectrometer capable of operation from a remotely operated vehicle to ocean depths of about 3000 m. LIBS utilizes a laser focused to a beam of order 10 μm in diameter to create a plasma or “laser spark” once the power density exceeds the breakdown threshold of the material. A gated spectrometer  covering part or all of the ultraviolet through near infrared range (200-1000 nm wavelength) is used to capture the plasma spectrum. This relatively simple apparatus yields simultaneous sensitivity to many elements in the parts-per-million (ppm) range in solids, liquids, gases and aerosols. An in situ chemical sensor with the characteristics of LIBS has myriad applications in chemical, geological, and biological oceanography in regimes ranging from the laboratory to estuaries to the coastal zone to the deep ocean.The specific target of this work was hydrothermal vents at mid-ocean ridges where seawater circulates through the fractured and permeable oceanic crust. Exit temperatures at discrete, focused high temperature vents range from 200-405°C at ambient pressures of 150-500 atmospheres.

The project presented a number of scientific and engineering challenges that were in the end overcome. The most important of these was housing the spectrometer in a pressure case that could contain all of the electronic and optical subsystems required for operation. We fortuitously located a grade 5 27" diameter spherical titanium housing originally fabricated for the Apollo moon program that fulfilled our needs. The optical train was then designed constrained by the spherical geometry. The optical train interfaces to an optical tube “lance” extending from it (Figure 1 left). The optical tube has o-ring seals at the spherical pressure housing interface, so that a failure of the tube will not compromise the expensive laser and spectrometer in the sphere (Figure 1 right). The optical tube serves to place the vent at a safe distance from the spherical housing, with optics contained at the distal end. The pressure window between the optics and the ocean is sapphire, so that accidental, brief insertion into a vent should not compromise the optical tube. 

A completely unexpected effect that ensued was the presence of a strong signal centered at ~649 nm and extending at the base over ~630-690 nm. This was subsequently identified as due to stimulated Raman (SR). SR for the strong OH band of water occurs at 649 nm when 532 nm excitation is used, and is highly directional, counter propagating exactly along the excitation beam. This was subsequently investigated in Angel’s lab at the University of South Carolina, where it has now been shown that SR can be eliminated by lowering the laser power and increasing the gate time. This allows the lithium line at 671 nm to be measured, which was an important goal of the project.

The final optical design was then evaluated using solutes of varying concentration in deionized water to establish the limit of detection (LOD) of the new spectrometer design. Immersing the entire spectrometer in a test tank containing reagents at varying concentration is impractical (and would require very large amounts of expensive reagents), and so the system was operated in the laboratory using all of the components (i.e., all of the optical train, including the sapphire window) interfaced to a small acrylic test tank containing ~2 l iters of fluid. The LODs (expressed in ppm of the relevant ion) for Ca, Na, K and Mn are 40, 0.5, 30 and 500 ppm, respectively. This compares to laboratory values (using a 532 nm laser wavelength and the same spectrometer and laser) of 50, 0.1, 10 and 50 ppm, respectively. Since the focal length used in the laboratory was 3.5 cm compared to 9 cm in the new design, it was expected that the new design should have an LOD about (9/3.5)2≈7 times higher due to inverse square spreading. We are clearly doing better than that for the first three elements. The Mn numbers were subsequently found to be invalid due to hydration of the MnSO4 solute. We expect to be able to measure Li with an LOD of about 0.5 ppm by extrapolating the performance for Ca, Na and K using the results from Angel’s lab. These LODs are well below values that are useful for hydrothermal vent studies.

The LIBS spectrometer is ready for validation at a hydrothermal vent, and will then be made available to the hydrothermal vent science community. This will faciliate the simultaneous measurement of the concentrations of five key elements in real-time, along with the interrelationships between them.
